fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The map \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \to \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ) induced by \underline {\mathbb {C}}\to \Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet identifies \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) with a direct factor of \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ).

Let \varepsilon \colon X_\bullet \to X be an augmented simplicial scheme over X. Suppose that \varepsilon is a proper hypercover, and that the X_n are smooth. We have the commutative diagram
361hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1.xmlEquation9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2
\usepackage {amsmath} \usepackage {amssymb} \usepackage {tikz-cd} \begin {tikzcd} \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [r,"\sim "] \ar [r,swap,"(1)"] \ar [d] & \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [d,"\sim "] \ar [d,swap,"(2)"] \\\operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) \ar [r] & \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet ) & (9.3.2.1) \end {tikzcd}
The arrow (1) is bijective by (II) and (IV) of . The arrow (2) is bijective since \Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet is a resolution of \underline {\mathbb {C}} (the Poincaré lemma on the X_n). The diagram gives a retract, compatible with the cup product, of \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) onto \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}), and this proves .

fr:title.text: Hodge Theory III › Examples and applications › Construction of complexes of first-order differential operators

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Hodge Theory III › Examples and applications › Construction of complexes of first-order differential operators

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This section depends only on and . We will prove the following theorem.

Let X be a quasi-projective scheme (over \mathbb {C}). Then there exists on X a complex K of sheaves that satisfies the following properties.
The K^n are coherent algebraic sheaves, and K^n=0 for n<0.
The differentials \mathrm {d}\colon K^n\to K^{n+1} are algebraic differential operators of order 1.
The complex K^\mathrm {an} of coherent analytic sheaves on X^\mathrm {an} is a resolution of the constant sheaf \underline {\mathbb {C}}. More precisely, \operatorname {\mathscr {H}}^i(K)=0 for i>0, and there exists f\colon \Omega _X^\bullet \to K with f^n linear algebraic, such that the composite map \underline {\mathbb {C}}\to \mathcal {O}_X\xrightarrow {f^0}K^0 identifies \underline {\mathbb {C}} with \operatorname {\mathscr {H}}^0(K).
The natural map \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^i(X,K) \to \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^i(X^\mathrm {an},K^\mathrm {an}) \xleftarrow [\text {(c)}]{\sim } \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^i(X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) is an isomorphism.
As a corollary, we recover a particular case of a theorem of Bloom and Herrera [BH1969].
We will first prove the corollary. The proposition will be obtained by redoing the proof at the level of complexes.

The map \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \to \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ) induced by \underline {\mathbb {C}}\to \Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet identifies \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) with a direct factor of \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ).

Let \varepsilon \colon X_\bullet \to X be an augmented simplicial scheme over X. Suppose that \varepsilon is a proper hypercover, and that the X_n are smooth. We have the commutative diagram
361hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1.xmlEquation9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2
\usepackage {amsmath} \usepackage {amssymb} \usepackage {tikz-cd} \begin {tikzcd} \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [r,"\sim "] \ar [r,swap,"(1)"] \ar [d] & \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [d,"\sim "] \ar [d,swap,"(2)"] \\\operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) \ar [r] & \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet ) & (9.3.2.1) \end {tikzcd}
The arrow (1) is bijective by (II) and (IV) of . The arrow (2) is bijective since \Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet is a resolution of \underline {\mathbb {C}} (the Poincaré lemma on the X_n). The diagram gives a retract, compatible with the cup product, of \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) onto \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}), and this proves .

The complex K that we wish to construct is, in the derived category, exactly \mathrm {s}\mathrm {R}{\varepsilon _\bullet }_*\Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet . We will only deal with the case where the augmented simplicial space X_\bullet is s-split, defined as in by proper and surjective maps, with smooth quasi-projective sources f'_k\colon N_k \to (\operatorname {cosq}\operatorname {sq}_{k-1}(X_\bullet ))_k for k\geqslant 0.

We will construct a "compatible system" of affine open covers of the X_n. It will be relevant, for this construction, to consider an open cover of a space Y as a diagram Y \xleftarrow {u} U \xrightarrow {\varphi } I where I is discrete, u is surjective, and u_i\colon U_i\coloneqq \varphi ^{-1}(i)\hookrightarrow Y is an open embedding. Proceeding as in , we construct a diagram
363hodge-theory-iii-9.3.3.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.3.1.xmlEquation9.3.3.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.3 X_\bullet \xleftarrow {u} U_\bullet \xrightarrow {\varphi } I_\bullet \tag{9.3.3.1}
of the following type.
I_\bullet is a discrete simplicial set. The I_n are finite.
For all k\geqslant 0, induces a diagram
\usepackage {amsmath} \usepackage {amssymb} \usepackage {tikz-cd} \begin {tikzcd} (\operatorname {cosq}\operatorname {sq}_{k-1}(X_\bullet ))_k & (\operatorname {cosq}\operatorname {sq}_{k-1}(U_\bullet ))_k \ar [l] \ar [r,"\varphi "] & (\operatorname {cosq}\operatorname {sq}_{k-1}(I_\bullet ))_k \\N_k \ar [u,"f'_k"] & N_k(U_\bullet ) \ar [u] \ar [l] \ar [r,swap,"\varphi "] & N_k(I_\bullet ) \ar [u,swap,"a'_k"] \end {tikzcd}
In

The map \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \to \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ) induced by \underline {\mathbb {C}}\to \Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet identifies \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) with a direct factor of \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ).

Let \varepsilon \colon X_\bullet \to X be an augmented simplicial scheme over X. Suppose that \varepsilon is a proper hypercover, and that the X_n are smooth. We have the commutative diagram
361hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1.xmlEquation9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2
\usepackage {amsmath} \usepackage {amssymb} \usepackage {tikz-cd} \begin {tikzcd} \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [r,"\sim "] \ar [r,swap,"(1)"] \ar [d] & \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [d,"\sim "] \ar [d,swap,"(2)"] \\\operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) \ar [r] & \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet ) & (9.3.2.1) \end {tikzcd}
The arrow (1) is bijective by (II) and (IV) of . The arrow (2) is bijective since \Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet is a resolution of \underline {\mathbb {C}} (the Poincaré lemma on the X_n). The diagram gives a retract, compatible with the cup product, of \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) onto \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}), and this proves .

The fundamental results, proven in [SD], are the following.
The continuous maps of universal cohomological descent form a Grothendieck topology on the category of topological spaces, which we call the universal cohomological descent topology.
A proper () surjective map is of universal cohomological descent.
A map a\colon X\to S that admits sections locally on S is of universal cohomological descent.
Let a\colon X_\bullet \to S be a k-truncated augmented simplicial space (with -1\leqslant k\leqslant \infty ). For k\geqslant n\geqslant -1, let \varphi _n\colon \operatorname {cosq} X_\bullet \to \operatorname {cosq}\operatorname {sq}_n X_\bullet be the evident map. We say that X_\bullet is a k-truncated hypercover of S, for the universal cohomological descent topology, if the maps
2180hodge-theory-iii-5.3.5.1hodge-theory-iii-5.3.5.1.xmlEquation5.3.5.1hodge-theory-iii-5.3.5 (\varphi _n)_{n+1} \colon X_{n+1} \to (\operatorname {cosq}\operatorname {sq}_n X_\bullet )_{n+1} \tag{5.3.5.1}
(for -1\leqslant n\leqslant k-1) are of universal cohomological descent. If X_\bullet is such a hypercover, then the simplicial space \operatorname {cosq}(X_\bullet ) augmented over S is of cohomological descent.
Let a be a morphism of simplicial topological spaces augmented over S. \begin {CD} X_\bullet @>a>> Y_\bullet \\@VxVV @VVyV \\S @= S \end {CD} We say that a is a hypercover for the universal cohomological descent topology if the evident maps X_n\to (\operatorname {cosq}_{n-1}^{Y_\bullet }\operatorname {sq}_{n-1}X_\bullet )_n are of universal cohomological descent. If a is such a hypercover then, for every K\in \operatorname {Ob}\mathrm {D}^+(S), a^*\colon \mathrm {R} y_*y^*K \xrightarrow {\sim } \mathrm {R} x_*x^*K.

The map \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \to \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ) induced by \underline {\mathbb {C}}\to \Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet identifies \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) with a direct factor of \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X^\mathrm {an}}^\bullet ).

Let \varepsilon \colon X_\bullet \to X be an augmented simplicial scheme over X. Suppose that \varepsilon is a proper hypercover, and that the X_n are smooth. We have the commutative diagram
361hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2.1.xmlEquation9.3.2.1hodge-theory-iii-9.3.2
\usepackage {amsmath} \usepackage {amssymb} \usepackage {tikz-cd} \begin {tikzcd} \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [r,"\sim "] \ar [r,swap,"(1)"] \ar [d] & \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}) \ar [d,"\sim "] \ar [d,swap,"(2)"] \\\operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) \ar [r] & \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X_\bullet ^\mathrm {an},\Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet ) & (9.3.2.1) \end {tikzcd}
The arrow (1) is bijective by (II) and (IV) of . The arrow (2) is bijective since \Omega _{X_\bullet }^\bullet is a resolution of \underline {\mathbb {C}} (the Poincaré lemma on the X_n). The diagram gives a retract, compatible with the cup product, of \operatorname {\mathbb {H}}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\Omega _X^\bullet ) onto \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X^\mathrm {an},\mathbb {C}), and this proves .
